>    From: Ron Jeffries <ronjeffries@...>
> Subject: Re: My First mail
> 
> > 2. Can we generate the test cases automatically using JUnit. I think at least for the first time we are
> > supposed to write the first set of test cases manually. I know to write the test cases manually but how
> > can we generate the test cases automatically from the first set of manual ones?
> 
> Please give an example of some tests that you would want to generate
> automatically and tell us what you would get if you could do that.
 
As author of JUnitDoclet (the tool, Rick was kind enough to suggest) I'd like offer my two cents.

IMHO we should not depend on a generator to tell us how to test. After all, we test to understand what we are developing, right? If generating ALL the tests would be 
possible, how about generating the application in the first place?

But a generator can do things for us to make writing tests easy: it can generate a skeleton for the tests (test methods, TestCases, TestSuites) and keep it up to date as 
refactoring is changing our application. That's what JUnitDoclet does. Writing the assert* statements (the meat) is up to us developers. We know, what the program should 
do / or we learn just that by thinking about tests. And we should be able to extend generated test by manually written ones.

Would we tests accessor methods? Probably not. But didn't we all had copy/paste/errors with accessors (like a method getFirstName returning surName)? JUnitDoclet is 
looking for accessor pairs (with set/get/is) and is generating type depending tests for them. The developer doesn't have to do anything here, but now tests can find those 
stupid errors right away.

An example can be found here (click on step 1 to 6):
  http://www.junitdoclet.org/demo.html

 
Kind Regards,

Steffen Gemkow
